tn.ref: the word that came to Jeremiah from Yahweh
tn.text: AT: "Yahweh spoke his word to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]]
AT: "fighting against"
This refers to all the surrounding towns around Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this the same way you translated in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:32:26|Jeremiah 32:28]]

tn.ref: into the hand of the king of Babylon
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to control. AT: into the control of the king of Babylon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: You will not escape from his hand
tn.text: "You will not escape from his control"

tn.ref: Your eyes will look at the eyes of the king of Babylon; he will speak directly to you as you go to Babylon
tn.text: Both of these expressions mean the same thing, that he will see the king of Babylon in person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: You will not die by the sword. You will die in peace
tn.text: AT: "You will not die in battle, but will die peacefully. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
These are names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: These cities of Judah remained as fortified cities
tn.text: AT: "the only fortified cities of Judah not yet captured"

tn.ref: This is the word that came to Jeremiah from Yahweh
tn.text: After this phrase, the reader will of course expct to see the content of the message from Yahweh. However, the actual message does not begin until [[:en:bible:notes:jer:34:12|39:12]]. For this reason, the translator may choose to omit this phrase here, and to follow the example of the UDB.
"message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came to
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]].

tn.ref: each man must send away his brother, his fellow Hebrew who had sold himself to you and served you
tn.text: AT: "each of you must free any fellow Hebrews who sold themselves to you and have been your slaves"
AT: "You must let them be free from serving you"

tn.ref: did not listen to me and or pay attention
tn.text: Both these phrase are saying basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"correct" or "acceptable" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "stopped doing what was right and did evil things that have made people think that I am evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: So look! I am about to proclaim freedom to you ... freedom for the sword, the plague, and famine
tn.text: AT: "So because you have not obeyed me, I will allow you to be punished by the sword, the plague, and famine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
"Listen!" or "Pay attention to the important thing I am going to tell you!"
AT: "agreed to with me"
AT: "seeking to kill them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
"come to fight"
Here "them" refers to the armies of the nation of Babylon. AT: "and will bring the Babylonian army back"
